race.name: Cheaha Challenge
race.tagline: Alabama Cheaha Mountain gravel in Jacksonville.

climate.description: Variable conditions with heat and humidity possible.

terrain.surface: Gravel roads through Cheaha Mountain area. Significant elevation with mountain scenery.

gravel_god_rating.score_note: Regional AL event. Cheaha Mountain terrain is nice but moderate organization and regional field.

biased_opinion.summary: Cheaha Challenge is a regional event in Jacksonville, northeast Alabama near Cheaha Mountain. The mountain terrain offers significant climbing with mountain scenery, but the moderate organization and regional field keep it firmly in Tier 3. Jacksonville provides moderate access. It's a solid regional event for Alabama cyclists.
biased_opinion.bottom_line: A solid regional Alabama gravel race with Cheaha Mountain terrain. Worth it for Alabama cyclists seeking a local mountain event. Not a destination race for out-of-state travelers.

final_verdict.one_liner: Alabama Cheaha Mountain gravel in Jacksonville.
final_verdict.should_you_race: If you're in Alabama and want a local Cheaha Mountain gravel event‚Äîyes, it's a solid regional race. If you're from out of state‚Äîthere are better options.
final_verdict.alternatives: For better Southeast events: Cohutta, Southern Cross. For similar regional events: other AL gravel races.

logistics.lodging_strategy: Jacksonville has moderate lodging options. Anniston has more options.
logistics.food: Small town with moderate dining. Stock nutrition.

marketplace_variables.race_hook: Alabama Cheaha Mountain gravel in Jacksonville.

logistics.explanation: Online registration closes Friday at noon, but they'll take walk-ups Saturday except for the Time Trial ‚Äî amateur hour planning. The Time Trial starts in Piedmont and finishes in Jacksonville with no transport provided back to your car. As Diane Schleicher noted after the pandemic gap, "It's been well over a year with no training rides. It's good to see people again." The logistics get riders together, even if execution is rough around the edges.

length.explanation: The 100-mile route packs 9,714 feet of climbing, while the ULTRA pushes 12,919 feet over 126 miles with 15% grades ‚Äî Andrew Knight crushed it in 4:19:34 in 2025. Course designers warn riders to "start early to avoid heat" and "maintain steady pacing" as "the elevation gain can tax your stamina." Distance options from 12 to 126 miles mean everyone from beginners to masochists can find their suffering level. Similar distance to Crusher in the Tushar.

technicality.explanation: Mount Cheaha gets climbed twice on the century course ‚Äî at mile 42 and mile 57 ‚Äî plus named climbs like White's Gap, Heflin Mountain, and "Not Again." The Time Trial runs 12.5 miles on Chief Ladiga Trail, described as "rough in spots, so please keep your head up while riding." This is sustained power climbing rather than technical handling, with "smooth pavement and occasional rough patches" through Talladega National Forest. Similar technical demands to Gravel Worlds.

elevation.explanation: The ULTRA delivers 12,919 feet of climbing over 126 miles with 15% grades that earned a 50% finish rate in its first year. The century route hits 9,714 feet including Mount Cheaha twice, with named climbs like "OH SHIFT!" and "Not Again" that locals designed because they "knew all aspects of Cheaha Mountain." Starting from Jacksonville at 650 feet and summiting Alabama's highest peak at 2,407 feet makes every climb count. More climbing than SBT GRVL at the same score.

climate.explanation: Historical weather data shows average highs of 80¬∞F and lows of 60¬∞F, with a 51% chance of rain on any given day. The 2025 event had a "weather delayed start" while 2021 enjoyed "all sunshine and blue skies." Despite promotional claims about "mild temperatures, clean air, and blue skies," riders need layered jerseys for "alpine breezes near the summit" and "sudden showers." The 7:30 AM start time and advice to "start early to avoid heat" suggest afternoon conditions can turn brutal in Alabama's May climate. More weather exposure than Belgian Waffle Ride San Diego.

altitude.explanation: Mount Cheaha at 2,407 feet is Alabama's highest point, starting from Jacksonville at 650 feet elevation. The 1,757-foot climb is substantial for the region but barely registers for altitude effects. This is sea-level suffering with hills, not mountain adaptation territory. Lower altitude than Gravel Worlds ‚Äî no thin-air concerns.

adventure.explanation: Mike Vickers founded this event with "a challenging bicycle ride up Cheaha Mountain," and colleagues' response was "Who in the world would want to do that?" The route follows Skyline Drive through "forested hills" that "open onto vast overlooks" across Talladega National Forest, summiting Alabama's highest peak twice on longer routes. Local course designers included climbs that "had to be there" rather than safe, predictable routes.

prestige.explanation: 31 years running with UCI qualifier status and 1,000 riders from 36 states and 6 countries shows solid regional draw. Top 25% finishers qualify for UCI Worlds, and it's rated one of the "Best Road Cycling Events in Southeast" by Strambecco. The growth from 80 Time Trial registrants in 2019 to 154 in 2021 indicates momentum, but it remains primarily a Southeast regional gran fondo rather than national destination.

race_quality.explanation: The ULTRA's 50% finish rate shows the course designers weren't messing around when they included climbs that "had to be there." With professional timing, medical support from JSU's College of Nursing, and up to 12 rest stops, the infrastructure supports serious racing. However, Nadia Pavlova's comment that "everything was canceled; I couldn't even plan anything" reflects the challenges of smaller regional events maintaining consistent quality.

experience.explanation: The post-race scene delivers with hot showers at the finish, buffet by Cooter's Rib Shack, and massage therapy on-site. Rest stops get creative ‚Äî "one year there was one with a Tour de France theme complete with the famous Tour devil, a small Eiffel Tower and even two pretty podium girls." ULTRA finishers get custom shirts while non-finishers "will receive the ashes of their burned shirts" ‚Äî a motivational touch that sticks with you.

community.explanation: "Every time a name was called the cyclists cheered like their own kids were winning trophies" at the 2021 awards ceremony captures the family atmosphere. As Ride Director Brooke Nelson noted, "The pandemic has made all of us so ready and so thankful to have something to do." The event started as a recreational ride where riders could "participate with the goal of racing the course to get a fast time, while others would start with the singular goal of simply finishing."

field_depth.explanation: Andrew Knight's back-to-back wins in 4:33:18 (2024) and 4:19:34 (2025) suggest limited elite competition. Emma Drabbe took women's honors in 4:52:25, down from Lisa Houser's 5:07:48 the previous year. UCI qualifier status brings some depth ‚Äî top 25% qualify for Worlds ‚Äî but with only overall awards for century and ULTRA winners, the competitive structure remains basic for a 1,000-rider field. Less competitive depth than Almanzo 100.

value.explanation: Seven distance options from 12 to 126 miles, plus separate Time Trial and Chief Ladiga Cruise, give riders choices for their suffering preference. The package includes free pre-ride breakfast at JSU, professional timing, medical support, and post-ride buffet by Cooter's Rib Shack. Pre-ride party at $15 and "undoubtedly one of the best-supported century rides anywhere" with creative rest stops delivers solid bang for buck in Alabama cycling.

expenses.explanation: Registration runs $60-100. Jacksonville, Alabama isn't breaking any budgets ‚Äî local dining includes "award-winning barbeque restaurants" and the town's 12,548 population keeps lodging affordable. Essential gear includes hydration packs since "hydration points are limited along the route," but that's smart preparation rather than forced expense. The Time Trial's Piedmont-to-Jacksonville route requires transport arrangement back to your car, more logistical hassle than major expense. Similar expense level to Belgian Waffle Ride San Diego.

rider_intel.search_text: The Cheaha Challenge in Jacksonville, Alabama is a 65-mile gravel race with 6000 feet of elevation gain that has become widely known in the cycling community and brings positive economic impact to the county. According to race coverage, the event attracts long-distance cycling enthusiasts to the area. However, safety concerns have been documented, with at least one incident involving a cyclist being shot with a pellet rifle approximately seven miles from the finish line during a race. Despite the injury requiring medical attention, the affected rider completed the race. Law enforcement investigated the incident, which was linked to similar shootings in the White Plains community area. The race takes place in rural Alabama terrain where cyclists may encounter various road users and conditions typical of the region.
